image.altText: A close-up of the backs of the heads of two Aboriginal children.

title.children: Sarah does 90 per cent of her grocery shopping online — but she's not checking out at the big supermarkets

image.altText: An illustration of a person's hand placing a ballot paper into a ballot box held by someone else's outstretched hands.

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: Albanese says more than 600,000 people have voted early in Voice referendum

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As I mentioned earlier, the prime minister says more than 600,000 Australians have voted early. Early referendum voting opened across the country this week. You can find an early polling location near you using the AEC's 'Where Can I Vote?' tool. Below are the reasons why you can vote early in the Voice referendum: You are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote You are more than 8km from a polling place You are travelling You can't leave your workplace to vote You are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or are caring for someone who is) You are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital You have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place You are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained You are a silent elector You have a reasonable fear for your safety You can read more about whether you are eligible to vote early here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How to vote early in the Voice referendum

featuredLink.title: Here's how to vote early in the referendum and who's eligible

props.alt: Five people have their heads down and backs towards the camera looking at a piece of paper.

children.content: Early voting has kicked off around the country.
(ABC Gippsland: Kerrin Thomas)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Postal vote applications for the Voice referendum close on October 11. Here are several reasons why you can apply for a single event postal vote if you can't get to a polling place on voting day: You are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote You are more than 8km from a polling place You are travelling You can't leave your workplace to vote You are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or are caring for someone who is) You are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital You have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place You are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained You are a silent elector You have a reasonable fear for your safety You can read more on whether you are eligible to apply for a postal vote here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Applying for a postal vote

featuredLink.title: Voice to Parliament referendum postal vote applications are open

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says more than 600,000 people have voted early in the referendum. "I take great heart in that, that Australians are eager to vote 'Yes' in this referendum because they know what it's about is just two things: recognition of First Nations people in our nation's founding document and secondly about a non-binding advisory committee," he said. "That's all this is. [It's] to give advice on matters affecting Indigenous Australians, because if you do that, if you listen to people, you get better outcomes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says more than 600,000 Australians have voted

image.altText: A woman and her son sit on a bench near a tree in the sun.

items.synopsis: Nagorno-Karabakh is trapped in the eye of a swirling geopolitical storm of duelling world powers. For decades, Russia has played a role in mediating conflict around the enclave, but Azerbaijan’s move to take back the area has exposed Moscow's waning influence.

title.children: A crisis unfolding in Putin's backyard has exposed the ripple effects of his dwindling power

image.altText: A number of people cross an intersection in Brisbane's CBD. Behind them are office buildings.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market follows Wall Street's lead and is trading substantially lower, after stronger-than-expected jobs data in the US stoked fears among investors that interest rates would remain higher for longer. Follow live.

title.children: ASX hits 11-month low after stronger-than-expected US jobs data stokes 'higher for longer' interest rate fears

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian sharemarket remains deeply in negative territory as of 12:30pm AEDT, down 0.7% to 6,895 points. (For live figures at any time, head to the top of the blog). The fall means the ASX is now at its lowest level since November 7 last year, after dropping to its lowest point in more than six months at the close of trade yesterday. Between the RBA flagging future rate hikes and worries about the US labour market and the Federal Reserve's next rate decision, investors are feeling jittery to say the least. Utilities is the only sector seeing positive gains, up 0.6%. All other sectors are in the red, with technology down 1.6%, i ndustrials down 1.5%, and real estate falling by 1.3%. The top movers right now are: Ramelius Resources +2.7% Nufarm +1.8% Orora +1.7% IPH +1.6% Gold Road Resources +1.6% And the bottom performers right now: Core Lithium -6% Weebit Nano -4.5% Polynovo -4.4% Virgin Money UK -4.2% Nanosonics -3.9%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX hits 11-month low as tech, financial stocks drag on rate hike risk

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to recently released analysis from Moody's Investor Services. They say residential mortgage delinquency rates, or the rate at which borrowers have failed to meet their repayments, will continue to rise for the rest of the year as high interest rates and inflation wear down household savings. Data for the latest for residential mortgage-backed securities (RMBS) from Moody's shows that that the share of prime quality home loans that were at least 30 days in arrears (30+ days delinquency rate) was 1.38% in June 2023, up from 1.25% in March — but are lower than the peak of 1.76% seen during COVID. "While the Reserve Bank of Australia has paused its cycle of interest rates rises, the central bank's steep rate hikes ... have considerably raised mortgage repayment costs ," said Moody's Investors Service vice president, Alena Chen. "Additionally, inflation, while easing from recent peaks, remains well above the RBA's target range at 5.2%, which means borrowers have to contend with elevated consumer prices and that high interest rates will likely persist for some time. "The combination of high interest rates and inflation has materially reduced Australia's household savings ratio to 3.2% (the lowest level since 2008), which is weakening the capacity of financially vulnerable borrowers to meet mortgage repayments." The report also notes that a number of mortgages are set to come off their lower fixed-rate periods by the end of the year onto higher, variable loans, which will increase the risk of mortgage stress. "We expect mortgage delinquencies will only rise moderately, because Australia's low unemployment rate (3.7% in August) and recovering housing prices will mitigate risks for borrowers," Ms Chen said. "Additionally, lenders have substantially cut back on risky mortgage lending over recent years, which will further mitigate risks."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mortgage delinquency rates to continue rising as borrowers run down savings

mortgage delinquencies will only rise moderately

lenders have substantially cut back on risky mortgage lending over recent years
, which will further mitigate risks."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With petrol prices sticking well above $2 a litre in capital cities, the federal government is facing renewed pressure to step in and provide some relief for motorists by reinstating the fuel excise discount. The fuel excise is the tax on petrol and diesel that's levied by the federal government. It was cut by 22 cents a litre last year, but the Albanese government allowed it to expire. Yesterday the PM was asked if he'd consider cutting the excise again, to which Anthony Albanese said he doesn't make tax policy on the run. But energy economist at the Commonwealth Bank, Vivek Dhar says it isn't the tax that's keeping the prices high — it's all got to do with oil prices. "We have seen OPEC+, which is a group of countries that control about 40 per cent of global supply, effectively reduce production which has led to this higher oil price environment ," he said. "So that's been really the key driver of higher petrol prices, but what's made this situation worse has been the weakening in the Australian dollar ." For those who are hoping for relief at the bowser, Mr Dhar says we can expect to be waiting a while. "There has been an interesting drop in oil prices over the last in 2-3 trading sessions, that's been a 5% fall, so that will give some reprieve," he said. "But our concern is any fall in oil prices will be almost mitigated by falls in the Australian dollar. "We may be stuck in this petrol price environment of 2.10 to 2.20 a litre for the foreseeable future ... we're thinking [falls are] more a story for early 2024." — Reporting by political reporter Evelyn Manfield
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal government showing no signs of reinstating fuel excise discount

It was
cut by 22 cents a litre last year
, but the Albanese government allowed it to expire.
Yesterday the PM was asked if he'd consider cutting the excise again, to which Anthony Albanese said he doesn't make tax policy on the run.
But energy economist at the Commonwealth Bank,
Vivek Dhar
says it isn't the tax that's keeping the prices high — it's all got to do with
oil prices
"We have seen OPEC+, which is a group of countries that control about 40 per cent of global supply,
effectively reduce production which has led to this higher oil price environment
," he said.
"So that's been really the key driver of higher petrol prices, but
what's made this situation worse has been the weakening in the Australian dollar
For those who are hoping for relief at the bowser, Mr Dhar says we can expect to be waiting a while.
"There has been an interesting drop in oil prices over the last in 2-3 trading sessions, that's been a 5% fall, so that will give some reprieve," he said.
"But our concern is
any fall in oil prices will be almost mitigated by falls in the Australian dollar
"We may be
stuck in this petrol price environment of 2.10 to 2.20 a litre for the foreseeable future
... we're thinking [falls are] more a story for early 2024."
— Reporting by political reporter Evelyn Manfield
